title: 109_hr872
content: The Act may be cited as the "Improving Access to Nurse-Midwifery Care Act of 2005". Congress has authorized certified nurse-midwives (CNMs) to provide maternity-related services to Medicare-eligible women since 1988. In 1993, CNMs were also authorized to offer additional services outside the maternity cycle. Medicare reimburses CNMs for primary care services within their State-regulated scope of practice. The Medicare Payment Advisory Commission (MedPAC) recommended increasing part B reimbursement for CNM services in a June 2002 report to Congress. A 1998 study found that births attended by certified nurse-midwives (CNMs) had lower risks of infant death, neonatal mortality, and delivering low birth weight infants compared to births attended by physicians. Mean birth weight was also higher for CNM-attended births. Certified nurse-midwives (CNMs) attended a higher proportion of women at risk for poor birth outcomes, including African Americans, American Indians, teenagers, unmarried women, and those with lower education levels. Despite this, CNMs had better birth outcomes compared to physicians, even after accounting for socio-demographic and medical risk factors. Medicare covers 3,000,000 women with disabilities of childbearing age, who give birth to around 50,000 infants annually within the program. CNMs and certified midwives (CMs) are highly educated health professionals. Certified nurse-midwives (CNMs) and certified midwives (referred to as "CMs") are highly educated health professionals who require completion of a post-baccalaureate program, licensure, and passing a national certification exam. Inequitable reimbursement for obstetrical and gynecological services provided by CNMs or CMs can limit access to healthcare for women, especially those covered by Medicare. "Medicare payment for certified nurse-midwife and midwife services." Certified midwife services are defined as services provided by a certified midwife who has completed specific education and clinical experience requirements. These services must be legally authorized under State law and are payable under Medicare similarly to physician services. The heading in section 1861(gg) of the Social Security Act is amended to meet guidelines prescribed by the Secretary or certified by a recognized organization. The heading in section 1861(gg) of the Social Security Act is amended to include "Certified Nurse-Midwife Services; Certified Midwife Services". The Social Security Act is amended to include certified midwife services as part of the benefits. Patients under the care of a certified nurse-midwife or certified midwife can receive payment for their services. The Social Security Act is amended to include certified midwife services as part of the benefits, allowing certified nurse-midwives or certified midwives to provide and supervise services in hospitals. The Social Security Act is amended to include certified midwife services in hospitals, allowing certified nurse-midwives or certified midwives to provide and supervise services, subject to state law and hospital authorization. The Social Security Act is amended to include certified midwife services in hospitals, allowing certified nurse-midwives or certified midwives to provide and supervise services, subject to state law and hospital authorization. Additionally, Section 1832(a)(2)(B)(iii) is amended to allow certified nurse-midwife services or certified midwife services to be furnished in hospitals with teaching programs. The Social Security Act is amended to include certified midwife services in hospitals, allowing certified nurse-midwives or certified midwives to provide and supervise services. Payment amounts are adjusted to 100 percent, and assignment of payment is clarified for certified nurse-midwife services. The Social Security Act is amended to include certified midwife services in hospitals, allowing payment to be made to designated entities by certified nurse-midwives or certified midwives. Clarifications are provided regarding payments for services furnished in teaching hospitals. The Social Security Act is amended to include certified midwife services in hospitals, specifying payment conditions for certified nurse-midwives or certified midwives in teaching hospitals. The Secretary of Health and Human Services must create regulations within 180 days to implement the amendments related to physicians under the Act. The Secretary of Health and Human Services must promptly create interim regulations, after notice and public comment, within 6 months of the Act's enactment to implement the amendments.
